number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
3, 2015
												Mutant mayhemThe STALKER games have a reputation for being tough, and it’s well-deserved -- this is probably the most challenging single-player game I’ve played. Both the open world and the AI are very unforgiving. There are constant dangers not just from the wide variety of enemies but also from high levels of radiation and strange spatial anomalies. The Zone is a large place and during the course of the game you get to visit a diverse range of environments and encounter many weird malevolent forces. The combat is always demanding and requires a good deal of strategic thinking given that you have to deal with other health-depleting factors at the same time. The story, although it does suffer from the usual lack of focus as a result of non-linear gameplay and some uninspiring side quests, is still reasonably strong and engaging. Graphically it’s quite impressive, although I should point out that I installed the STALKER Complete 2009 mod from the get-go, which (as I understand it) improves on the vanilla game in this area. It’s true that there are some annoying bugs, but they didn’t dampen my enjoyment of the game too much. And even though the weapons and armour deteriorate (a feature I’m not overly fond of) the speed with which this occurs is more realistic than in many RPGs so it didn’t bug me too much. Overall the game scores very highly for its outstanding atmosphere, which is one of the most engrossing, and idiosyncratic, that I’ve encountered. Highly recommended. 4/5

												One of the best games I have ever played, simply due to the such realistic and heart destroying atmoshpere that is presnt within the game. Its inventory system is good and unique to the player as well as a vast array of weapons to choose from. The A-Life system within this game although old is still a masterpiece with animals and mutants behaving as they should and would if it were real life. The maps are really detailed, although on the ageing X-Ray Engine, graphics are still pretty good.The storyline within the game is accurate and very interesting as you ponder Chernobyl and Pripyats secrets.All S.T.A.L.K.E.R games to-date are equally brilliant and follow on from each other spectacularly.With supported mods such as S.T.A.L.K.E.R complete 2012, bugs are taken care of and lighting, textures as well as A.I behaviour are greatly improved although I reccomend doign a run through in vanilla first!If you could get a perfect game, in my view, this is it; which is why I was heart-broken when I heard S.T.A.L.K.E.R 2 was cancelled!10/10 would get jumpscared by a bloodsucker again!

												Strongly recommended.I first bought the game media DVD days after it was relased and reached my region... however, due to various reasons, I could not play it until now... those reasons were mainly language barrier (not native English, or good English at that time), so I could not understand much of the game back then... also my first encounter of the bloodsucker :D it made me jump on my seat... (I'll never forget that moment :D), so I thought: this is not the right time to play this game...I kept it in the shelve collecting dust, ignoring it, and I thought I wasted my money on it...Now, I got it on steam, and finally I could understand English well, so I thought, why not give it a try and see what is this game really is?I installed the 3 games, and started with SoC 2 weeks ago, and I just finished it...This game is now my number one game and I loved every single moment of it while I was playing... I lived with the main character through every single corner and place of it, and I will not forget my time playing this game...I will replay it, and I will make different choices through the game, again and again... I will not get bored of it I'm sure of this...This game has everything, RPG (of course), action, horror, mysteries, stealth and sneaking, and even some drama...This series (the 3 games Shadow of Chernobyl, Clear Sky, and Call of Pripyat), made me feel really sad for that there will be no STALKER II of it... and I really hope that a day will come and I see this got a "II" after its name...I definately recommend this to every single gamer who want adventure and all types of game play mixed in 1 game...This should get more hype and more known over some "big" titles out there.

content:
8, 2014
												In my opinion, this is one of the all time greats of PC gaming; a true work of genius.  Not only is it a fantastic horror-themed game, but it also sports one of the best gun-based combat engines I've ever used in any game.  But I think what I like the best about the game are the incredible atmospherics.  Between the vast swaths of abandoned structures that you can explore, and the wonderful dynamic weather system, Stalker is a game that truly and deeply immerses you in a terrifying alternate reality.  Truly, I cannot say enough about this bona fide classic.  PS:  And don't let its age scare you away.  Get the easy to install Stalker Complete mod, and this game looks and runs just fine on a modern rig.  Also, be sure to read Roadside Picnic, and watch the movie Stalker, for a better idea of the origins of the Zone.

, 2015
												Shadow of Chernobyl is a fun and expansive game set in "The Zone", an area of Ukraine that was directly affected by the Chernobyl Plant disaster. With that out of the way, I'd like to get down to why this game is so incredible. Atmosphere. You wont find a game that pulls you in and holds you there quite like a Stalker game. The game has a way of simply including you in the zone, making you feel as if every encounter is life or death and the moments in between are a sweet breath of fresh air. I tell you, there's nothing like coming in from the clustering darkness to an old railway station after fighting off hordes of obnoxiously intelligent (and I'm being serious, STALKER ai is frightening to fight against, and is rumored to be able to complete the game on their own) bandits to find a group of fellow Stalkers and rookies huddled around a trashcan fire, speaking softly in Russian, knowing in here, around friends, just for tonight- You're safe.Shootouts are frequent and heart pounding. It's recommended you play on Master difficulty with the crosshairs disabled. You and your target are likely to go down in a few hits. As I said before, the Ai is frighteningly intelligent. They will actively move towards you if they can, flanking and moving from cover to cover, plunking shots all the while. This makes choosing your cover very important, and forces you to keep a close eye on who your fighting with. All too often I've damn near ♥♥♥♥ myself because I let a bandit come up behind me while I was trading shots with a few of his buddies in a run down far. Speaking of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ oneself, The Zone is not only populated with bandits, but monsters as well, all of them designed and built around fear.STALKER is an RPG of sorts. You've got an inventory system, weight system, you need to eat every so often, there's an economy, weapons and armor to pick from, factions and reputation- It's got it all. Will I tell you it's done well? Not all of it. Don't expect to level up or pick our perks. That can somewhat be accomplished by recovering artifacts, but it's certainly not the same. Still, that's no reason to not check out the game. STALKER in the end is a fun and terrifying game, one that makes you feel like a rugged post-apocalyptic Ukranian artifact hunter and full time bandit/creature slayer. Shadow of Chernobyl comes highly recommended, and once you've done a vanilla play through, there's an abundance of mods to try out. Then go on to pick up CS and Call of Pripyat. Good hunting, Stalkers.

												This s probably one of the most amazing FPS i have ever played, yes it has its bugs like "multiple spawns" NPCs without collision,one or two missions broken..The atmosphere is fantastic and unlike any other game out there. it was in development for years and even though they didn't manage to include everything they wanted, what they did is still incredible. this is no Console shooter or port, if you want a simple run and gun don't buy it and play for 20 minutes and complain when unlike Crysis you can't kill everything in 10 seconds with your hitech gun and invincible p0ssy suit.,Gameplay is about doing quests, roaming around the Chernobyl zone, avoiding deadly "anomalies" and radiactive area and battling with bandits, military, mutants and aggressive wildlife.Zone represent area around Chernobyl with forests, plains, city of Pripyat, nuclear plant...The game is mostly FPS but RPG elements are very strong.Models and textures are a bit outdated but light and shadows are very impressive.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												Stalker may be the crown-jewel of Slavic post-apocalyptic games, surpassing even Metro 2033. With beautiful environments, a haunting ambient soundtrack, and vicious monsters, Stalker sets a dark tone for this survival-horror shooter. However, you will find that, unlike Metro 2033, humans play as great as threat as the monsters, perhaps even more so depending on how you play. With dozens of weapons, quests, and characters, you will be well prepared to discover all of Chernobyl's secrets. What is more, compared to Western post-apocalyptic games such as Fallout, Stalker possesses a much deeper and more intense story, especially towards the end, when the truth is revealed. Normally I would never recommend mods for a game, but in this case, I believe that Stalker Complete is well worth it, removing/fixing multiple glitches, and thus contributing to a smoother game. Overall, despite the savage nature of the environment, one cannot help but be impressed with how beautifully the developers strung together the story and characters. Overall Score: 10/10

content:
ber 2, 2015
												Whoever praises Fallout 3 and New Vegas, should have firstly played this game.I'm not saying this game is better than Fallout 3, I'm just saying that this title is the real post-apocalyptic FPS experience.So many years have passed and now I've played this game also on Steam, and I must say that even if time passes by, this game never gets old.Let's start with the main point of this game: gameplay.Not considering the RPG style inventory and quest system, the ballistic of weapons is something you don't see often so well made in an FPS.After handling well a weapon, you acquire the skill to use it right, and every weapon feels different.Enemy's AI is another great point in favor: they always know how to catch you the right way, disregarding of the place, and their movements are always smart and unpredictable.I think this AI is smartest than F.E.A.R.'s one, and probably the best I've ever seen in an FPS.Graphics are very good, even if a bit dated. The entire zones are fully explorable and they are wonderfully designed.Sounds of weapons feel like having a gun in your hand and when you get hit, you can feel it on your skin.The overall experience is something very unique considering standard FPS games on the market.For the bad part: the game lack most of the fundamental tweaks, like fast travelling (yeah, this is pretty boring, especially because enemies respawn), the possibility to repair your equipment, time limited side quests and a fixed and low limit for carriage (I know it's "realistic" that your character can carry just 50 Kg, but it's a videogame and it's boring).The very bad of this game is the plot [SPOILER ALLERT]:Yeah, there may be some cool moments and twists, but the story is pretty stupid (go there, then there, then I need you to take that and carry it on there...) and the only narrative value is the way it let you know the story behind the catastrophe, but as a character based story, it's not so interesting.Probably, the ending is the most disappointing thing of this game: almost all the endings have a pretty stupid horrifying theme and they really don't satisfy the great work that the player have been done to accomplish all of this.I think this is one of these games that should be definitely be played by every FPS lover, after Half-Life and F.E.A.R.

content:
3, 2015
												Mutant mayhemThe STALKER games have a reputation for being tough, and it’s well-deserved -- this is probably the most challenging single-player game I’ve played. Both the open world and the AI are very unforgiving. There are constant dangers not just from the wide variety of enemies but also from high levels of radiation and strange spatial anomalies. The Zone is a large place and during the course of the game you get to visit a diverse range of environments and encounter many weird malevolent forces. The combat is always demanding and requires a good deal of strategic thinking given that you have to deal with other health-depleting factors at the same time. The story, although it does suffer from the usual lack of focus as a result of non-linear gameplay and some uninspiring side quests, is still reasonably strong and engaging. Graphically it’s quite impressive, although I should point out that I installed the STALKER Complete 2009 mod from the get-go, which (as I understand it) improves on the vanilla game in this area. It’s true that there are some annoying bugs, but they didn’t dampen my enjoyment of the game too much. And even though the weapons and armour deteriorate (a feature I’m not overly fond of) the speed with which this occurs is more realistic than in many RPGs so it didn’t bug me too much. Overall the game scores very highly for its outstanding atmosphere, which is one of the most engrossing, and idiosyncratic, that I’ve encountered. Highly recommended. 4/5

												Alright, this game for me would be a  9.5/10. This game is an immersive, free roam survival, and it does a damn good job at it. The storyline is one you can really wrap your head around. The gameplay throughout the story is intense action and fun at the same time. The game has a realistic fighting system with bleeding effects and radiation. There's also the mutants that you can fight with. If the story isn't good enough for you, there's tons of side missions and free roam exploration. You can even win favor from different factions in the game and get special weapons and suits from them only. The only problem is in this game you can't join factions and control them without mods. So if you like large free roam survival games, then get this.

content:
y 31, 2013
												STALKER Shadow of Chernobyl is one of the most atmospheric games I've played. Unlike many devs, the devs of STALKER paid ridiculous attention to small, near meaningless details, which together add up to a very immersive game. With fun gunplay, decent difficulty, a great story, and excellent exploration, this game deserves more than it's current "cult favourite" status.Protip: If you're going to play, play on Master difficulty, as on Master all weapons deal more damage (yours included!) and enemies have more advanced AI (flanking and such), leading to extremely fun and interesting firefights.Also has an absolutely brilliant modding community. I'd recommend trying out Zone Reclamation Project for a first playthrough, and AMK (difficulty), Zone of Alienation (Difficulty + immersion), or OGSE (Loads of new content) for a second/third/fourth/etc, playthrough.

												Challenging, well playing and scary. The need to eat and the fact that everything has a weight really makes this game feel truly immersive. It's atmosphere is unmatched, even by the Metro games. The world is very open but future STALKER games improve on making the world feel expansive and alive. The game is also very challenging but not unfair. As a whole the game is excellent. It may have a few bugs here and there, and the voice acting may be exceedingly Russian accented but it's very well presented. It also has a huge mod library; notable ones including Lost Alpha, the Complete edition, and Autumn Aurora. I'd recommend this to anyone who enjoys challenge and immersion.

content:

												This game is amazing, seriously. The base game is fun, but where this entire series shines is its modding community. If you get the base game, put on some mods to improve the buggy nature of the game, and maybe throw in an overhaul mod of your choice this game is completely unique. Imagine sitting down around a campfire, the night pitch black around you, as a rookie S.T.A.L.K.E.R. plays a guitar next to you while you check over your magazines and load them with some of the new bullets you bought. Suddenly, shots ring out and all of the rookies spring up as the military soldiers down the road finally decide to clear out the camp and you have to fight back decently armed soldiers with shotguns and submachine guns.This game can be incredibly immersive if you allow yourself to be drawn in, and I recommend it to anyone who isn't afraid of a difficult game and a realistic FPS.

content:
2012
												Challenging, well playing and scary. The need to eat and the fact that everything has a weight really makes this game feel truly immersive. It's atmosphere is unmatched, even by the Metro games. The world is very open but future STALKER games improve on making the world feel expansive and alive. The game is also very challenging but not unfair. As a whole the game is excellent. It may have a few bugs here and there, and the voice acting may be exceedingly Russian accented but it's very well presented. It also has a huge mod library; notable ones including Lost Alpha, the Complete edition, and Autumn Aurora. I'd recommend this to anyone who enjoys challenge and immersion.

content:
y 23, 2011
												Genius. One of the best and most atmospheric open-world FPS games I've played. This isn't really an RPG like The Elder Scrolls or Bethesda's Fallout games -- there are no levels or stats, no character creation, no classes or races to choose from... you are simply the Marked One, and your adventure is a bleak, lonely voyage around the mysterious and often hostile Zone. I would still like to see a game that approaches Tarkovsky's Stalker and its ideas a bit more subtly, but there's enough familiar stuff here to make things interesting for fans of that film and other sci-fi...

content:
r 21, 2016
												Completely brimming with bleak atmosphere, STALKER is a very immersive game. The wasteland feels very harsh and unforgiving, and many of the creatures that will be encountered are quite unnerving. Inventory management is always a concern, but does not feel like too much of a chore. Gunplay requires precision, and on the master difficulty you can ambush and kill enemies just as effectively as they can ambush and kill you. The game starts with the player feeling very weak, and this can be frustrating as going into every fight at a large disadvantage is rough, and requires liberal use of save files. However, once better equipment is obtained, the tables are turned! The player ends up being much stronger than most of the dangers of the Zone. This relieves a bit of the tension, but it does not trivialize the game's difficulty. Unfortunately, the story is a bit weak in this game, and many important plot threads are left as side-quests, which could cause a lot of important details to be skipped over unintentionally.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
r 7, 2015
												This is probably my favorite game of all time. The game has an amazing story. If you enjoy Russian/Ukrainian science fiction mixed with urban legend wrapped up in a big, beautiful plot twist bow, then this is the game for you. Although the story may feel patchy at times, I enjoyed it the whole way through. There are about 7 different endings, two of them being very special. This game effectively incorporates horror, action, and survival tactics into one large environment. This is a very immersive game; the audio is spectacular, the lighting system is top notch, the enemies are terrifying, and the combat system is well put together and feels good. There are plenty of enjoyable mods for this game which does increase the replay value. If you get this game, I highly suggest playing on the hardest difficulty. The game will be much more enjoyable. I never got into the faction system very much, but if you enjoy factions then it's a feature of the game. I did not experience very many bugs or glitches while playing this game, yet it seems that others have had a lot of difficulties with bugs and glitches. I believe the bugs and glitches in this game are hit or miss. Overall, this is a well made game with a superb story and I would suggest it to anyone who enjoys RPG-FPS style games.

content:
ber 15, 2015
												STALKER is a brilliant FPS that blends RPG and horror elements.What makes STALKER stand out is, hands down, the atmosphere. It's a semi-open world game where you can explore areas to find stashes and run into other stalkers and their respective factions. The stalkers are those that roam the zone, the area within and surrounding the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant. As you can imagine, the zone is infested with pockets of radiation that can cause severe harm, strange monsters roam about, people fight for survival, ecologists are simply trying to study, and you're at the center of it all.In the game, you play as the "Marked One", a stalker that was left for dead on a 'death truck'. Luckily for you, a fellow loner/stalker finds you and takes you to Cordon, where the gameplay begins. Because you're rescued by a fellow stalker who is employed by the local trader, you're tasked with a few missions and he also helps you set up your PDA where your sole mission that was already there is to "Kill Strelok". Who is Strelok? Well, play the game and find him, dammit.The story is really intricate, but let's shift away from that as it really boils down from going to area to area and accepting missions, sidequests, fighting in an arena for money, trading and selling goods, collecting weapons, ammo, etc. The story is really good by the way, but I just wanna talk about the gameplay. It's an FPS, duh. It's not like other FPS games, though, as it's more open in your choices, there are dialog options, albeit limited, and you can swap armor. It's not exactly an RPG, however, as there is no leveling system employed. And it's not a full on horror game as it's not terribly scary, there's just some really bizarre creatures that you run into. Most of the time, however, you'll be shooting other humans.The atmosphere is grimy, grey, and at some points, yellow, but not in a filtered Fallout 3 kind of way. It's natural lighting. Well, technically artificial, but you get the point. Buildings are destroyed, people speak about staying alive, playing guitars around a fire pit, smoking, laughing, drinking. The atmosphere is really cool with both the characters and how they interact and the world, itself.Pripryat shines in this game, the devs clearly took the time to research the city, the blueprints of the city, and I believe they visited the city as well, considering the devs are Ukrainians. As the devs are Ukrainians, that means the spoken language is accurate, the facial designs are accurate, etc. These guys knew what they were doing and they also did the scientific research as far as radiation pockets and possible effects of an expanding radiated zone. Very good game.9.2/10

content:
ry 3
												Similar quality to Fallout 3/Fallout New Vegas except with a plethora of gopniks with guns instead of ghouls.  More bleak/harsh atmosphere than Fallout.  Practice your Russian as the npcs tend to blather on about I-Have-No-Freaking-Clue (but I can guess by tone).  At first the difficulty level and bullet registry will be challenging for even the most tempered fps adventurer.  Everyone is disposable, there are no women or children, no moralistic mantras being force-fed.  You're literally tossed out into this harsh environment to fend for yourself.  In soviet Russia toilet uses you.  Use your PDA -a Lot of information is there.  Don't know what this strange/weird symbol or thing is?  Search for Zone Survival Guide.  I typically like playing un-modded games however I highly recommend Zone Reclamation Project mod as an exception here.  It removes the idiotic quest time limits.  As an example:  you'll get an automated quest to save some stalkers in various areas from bandits.  You do that.  Your PDA says go pick up your reward which is 100 kilometers away, possibly in some area you've never been to before, all on foot -there is no fast travel/vehicles.  So you're supposed to hike all the way to wherever just to have some npc give you 2 bottles of vodka and a few rubles.  I play games for Fun, not time constraints.  Not like I was disarming a bomb.  So I removed those time constraints.Additionally, I tweaked the grid size for my inventory so I didn't have to scroll way, way, way down just to eat some bread.  ZRP with minor tweaks to the vanilla game makes this Excellent.  I would avoid all the other Complete/invasive mods that totally change the game.  It will likely sap the fun out of it/make you too overpowered.Graphics: pretty decent for when it came out  Sound/Music: really immersive/excellent  Gameplay/controls:  ASWD and very responsive  Area loadtimes/stutter:  some minor waits  Glitches: Haven't had too many occur -really stable and I'm nearing the end.  Bottomline: If you want a linear, story-driven game that holds your hand -this ain't it.  If you want an apocalyptic, Russian-themed game with tons of replay and choose-your-own-adventure, this is it.  A hidden gem worth the learning curve/difficulty.

												CHEEKI BREEKI I V DAMKEbut seriously, it's a story about a dude (played by you) who falls off a truck, and has amnesia, with only one note on your PDA: Find and kill someone named "Strelok". You are in the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, now mutated from the effects of the 1986 disaster. Explorers from outside the Zone have come in to find a new life, riches, to unlock the secrets of the Zone, and find out what's really going on in the center of the Zone at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant itself. People are paying money for STALKERs to recover strange artifacts from the hazardous anomalous areas of the Zone, so the eggheads can maybe find something to benefit humanity as a whole.Try to regain your memory, explore the Zone in a sandbox-style environment that lets you go where you want, without being shoehorned into linear corridor-style level progression, discover who you are, where Strelok is, and how he fits into all of this.♥♥♥♥ call of duty, S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is where it's at.

content:
ry 3
												Similar quality to Fallout 3/Fallout New Vegas except with a plethora of gopniks with guns instead of ghouls.  More bleak/harsh atmosphere than Fallout.  Practice your Russian as the npcs tend to blather on about I-Have-No-Freaking-Clue (but I can guess by tone).  At first the difficulty level and bullet registry will be challenging for even the most tempered fps adventurer.  Everyone is disposable, there are no women or children, no moralistic mantras being force-fed.  You're literally tossed out into this harsh environment to fend for yourself.  In soviet Russia toilet uses you.  Use your PDA -a Lot of information is there.  Don't know what this strange/weird symbol or thing is?  Search for Zone Survival Guide.  I typically like playing un-modded games however I highly recommend Zone Reclamation Project mod as an exception here.  It removes the idiotic quest time limits.  As an example:  you'll get an automated quest to save some stalkers in various areas from bandits.  You do that.  Your PDA says go pick up your reward which is 100 kilometers away, possibly in some area you've never been to before, all on foot -there is no fast travel/vehicles.  So you're supposed to hike all the way to wherever just to have some npc give you 2 bottles of vodka and a few rubles.  I play games for Fun, not time constraints.  Not like I was disarming a bomb.  So I removed those time constraints.Additionally, I tweaked the grid size for my inventory so I didn't have to scroll way, way, way down just to eat some bread.  ZRP with minor tweaks to the vanilla game makes this Excellent.  I would avoid all the other Complete/invasive mods that totally change the game.  It will likely sap the fun out of it/make you too overpowered.Graphics: pretty decent for when it came out  Sound/Music: really immersive/excellent  Gameplay/controls:  ASWD and very responsive  Area loadtimes/stutter:  some minor waits  Glitches: Haven't had too many occur -really stable and I'm nearing the end.  Bottomline: If you want a linear, story-driven game that holds your hand -this ain't it.  If you want an apocalyptic, Russian-themed game with tons of replay and choose-your-own-adventure, this is it.  A hidden gem worth the learning curve/difficulty.

content:
er 28, 2013
												This game is an incredible journey through the outlying areas near the Chernobyl Powerplant. The story is wonderfully crafted, the weapons get better as you progress, and you will always find a fight that is quite enjoyable. That being said, the game is buggy. Well, it was for me. But that didn't stop me as it was so amazing. The atmosphere really did wonders and the creepy dark noisy hallways and bunkers where you knew mutants were was just terrifying! This game is an FPS game with RPG mechanics. It is solid and didn't need DLC because the developers released the game complete and it was long enough by itself. If you want a more updated game, there are mods to make this game look brilliantly amazing considering what its limits are. All in all, great game.

er 30, 2013
												This is defintitely one of my favourite games. Once you disable the annoyingly shaky headbob, it's very easy to get absorbed in this wonderful world. The gameplay is great, the atmosphere is great, the story is... okay I guess, and the graphics really aren't that great, even for 2006. But graphics really don't matter at all. This game is GREAT. It definitely makes my top 10 list, maybe even top 5. However, if you are new or not very good at games, I wouldn't recommend this to you. It's VERY hard even on the easiest difficulty. Or maybe it's just because I'm playing it on a laptop. I DON'T KNOW. Again, great game, highly recommended, possibly the best atmosphere presented in ANY game, and if you care it's also easily modable. So yeah. I think it's worth the $20 and a MUST for any true PC gamer.

content:
y 4, 2013
												A classic RPG/FPS hybrid that has yet to find an equal in regards to atmosphere and gunplay. A must-have if you're a fan of shooters, but if you have a low tolerance for bugs you might want to look elsewhere -- vanilla STALKER has a lengthy Crime and Punishment-sized list of glitches, crashes, and game-breaking issues, but there are mods that minimize or fix most of these. Speaking of mods, there are a ton of them available for the game, and they do anything from restoring cut content or improving the aging graphics to adding whole new storylines, weapons, and areas.STALKER is an adventure game hidden in a first person shooter. Highly recommended!

												S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is a refreshing shooter in a world of mindless copy & paste shoot em' ups. It's enemy AI is still better than most modern day games even a decade later and the atmosphere is remarkably well done. While it has clunky or annoying aspects to it's design, such as weapon inaccuracy being a bit too exaggerated, enemies being somewhat bullet spongey (go for headshots) and the occasional bug, it provides a unique experience that may not be for everyone, but is worth checking out. Just remember to quick-save often. :)

content:
2, 2015
												(Just a note: I played this game on the highest difficulty and WITHOUT MODS and don’t come crying to me saying that you need to use mods for a better experience or something along those lines) Stalker shadow of Chernobyl is a free roaming fps game. Stalker takes place in what’s known as the zone after the nuclear incident in Chernobyl which has ruined a lot of the landscape, turned most animals into monsters, and poisoned a lot of areas with radiation and has created what are called anomalies which are murderous whether effects in one small spot, you play as a stalker (which stands for scavenger, trespasser, adventurer, loner, killer, explorer and robber) known as the marked one, you have amnesia and you are left with a PDA saying to kill some guy named Strelok, the story is almost non-existent but that doesn’t matter because a lot of games I play the story takes a huge backseat and doesn’t really matter that much. Stalker’s gameplay revolves around exploration, combat and completing quests and side quests which will give you rewards given to you by various people you’ll come across which will be marked on your PDA. In stalker you have an inventory system very similar to resident evil 4 where it’s a grid and each item will appear as a diagram and will take up space on the grid only you can stack all items, there’s weight limit with the inventory system: once you’re above the weight limit your stamina will drop extremely quickly if it will let you sprint. You have various suits and artefacts that you can find which all have different effects on the player such as resistance to radiation, reduction to how much you’ll bleed out when you are shot, an increase in stamina etc. You have a hunger and thirst system which you’ll need to use drinks and food when an icon appears on the right side of the screen, you’ll have to drink vodka or use certain medical equipment for when you have radiation poising and you’ll have to use bandages and med kits to stop you from bleeding out which both of these are notified by an icon that will appear on the right side of the screen. You can also trade items with various NPCs. There are also various enemy factions which you’ll come across in this game. It’s extremely difficult to say what’s to like about this game but one thing I can say is that this game is strangely compelling but it comes with a few glaring issues and problems.Stalker has some of the worst gunplay I’ve ever seen in any shooting game, most of the time you can’t hit what you’re aiming at, regardless of the distance between you and what you’re shooting at, regardless of whether you’re stood still or moving, regardless of your posture, regardless of whether you’re spraying or using burst fire or single shots and for the most part regardless of what weapon you’re using. However if you turn on the crosshair, unless the gun has a scope, hip firing is significantly more accurate than using iron sights,well when you put it on paper you are more accurate firing at a wall using iron sights from a distance but this magically disappears when shooting at an enemy, and hip firing is generally more effective against enemies and it also doesn’t help that the iron sights are horrible in this game and seriously get in the way. Even if you are going for the “realistic” way: DON’T, because iron sights are useless in this game (they’re better in the two sequels though)  The combat is just far too inconsistent in this game. In most games the enemies can hit you most if not every single time and the damage output is consistent and varies game to game, in Stalker the enemies have a completely random chance of hitting you, they also have a random damage output, so sometimes you’ll get just a scratch but others you’ll die instantly. A perfect examples of this is where I had to defend an area from a bandit raid, I was about 50 feet away from the enemies, they seemed to be unable to hit me until one of them suddenly and randomly did and I died instantly. You can go from an enemy noticing you and killing you instantly in one shot, then reload a save but this time that enemy might not be able to hit anything even when you are banzai charging towards them with the knife, which I have done before. Your success all comes down to retrying until you succeed because you got lucky, it doesn’t ever feel like skills matter in this game, and it’s, not like reaction time matters or anything in this it’s just ridiculous. There is the argument of “it’s trying to be realistic” no game is properly realistic, none, not even something such as Arma 3. I guess quite a fair bit in reality with wars can be down to luck but nothing like in this game. when you reload a save, the enemies go back to their starting positions and sometimes their starting positions are behind you and you’ll get killed right away when you’ve loaded a save.The movement in this game is almost headache inducing it does this really sickening head bobbing when you move, it sways to the bottom left and right really quickly. I’ve had an extremely difficult time deciding whether to recommend this game or not, I guess it all comes down to whether you think you can put up with these problems and I’m only recommending this game because I don’t hate it enough to not recommend it. Though after several playthroughs I like it significantly more than the first time I played this game. I have played this game with some mods but to be honest, you should just play the vanilla game because the mods don't really make much difference or properly improve the game, they all pretty much update the graphics, improve one or two features, overlook some of the issues and then add new ones on top, a lot of people say “oh it fixes all of the bugs”, well I can tell you I’ve played quite a bit of the vanilla game and I’ve NEVER come across a bug. There’s also a trend that’s been going around for a while with games such as the Stalker games, Oblivion, Skyrim, Fallout 3 and onward, where people think playing it with mods is better and they become complete elitist ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and have a massive go at people for playing the vanilla game and look down on them as if they are sub human. You can’t just ignore all of the problems with the vanilla game and say “oh but with this mod it’s great”, that’s like taking some really crappy games such as Ride to hell Retribution and that claiming playing it with mods is good, and the vanilla game matters the most. ♥♥♥♥ this trend, and all of the elitist people who support it.

ber 9, 2016
												Ignore people who say this game needs mods, the vanilla game is still excellent. I do recommend installing the Zone Reclamation Project, which for the most part is just a big community patch that makes the game run better with less bugs. Also, play on Master difficulty. Dispite what you might think, it doesn't make the game harder, but is how the game was intended to be played, making the enemies easier to kill. (they can kill you more easily too though.)One of my favorite games. I don't thing any games atmosphere can even come close to what STALKER has. The game has some genuinly scary sections, great weather effects, excellent sounds and it looks fantastic despite it's age.

												Quite a fun game, well worth a play, but be warned it is SO easy to break the sequence and cause the entire story to be broken. If you do the wrong mission at the wrong time an entire group of people you need to talk to in order to continue the story will attack you on sight, and this is not a fixable problem.You also have to travel to different regions quite often, so the effects of this might not be completely obvious to you until it's too late.Aside from that, the mechanics are spot on, the survival requirements are real, the feeling of satisfaction when you get new gear or conquer a new area is awesome, and the mods available are damn cool as well.

content:
er 3, 2016
												SoC is hard to describe. It's both the best and the worst of the series. It's a lot like Lost Planet in that regard.Let me start by saying it's as buggy as maggots in cow ♥♥♥♥. If you can't deal with that, I can't recommend the game. You're going to have at least one crash. In my experience, I actually had to heal manually-- using items on bodies crashed the game. I'd look past the bugs though. Stalker SoC is the perfect mix of story, combat, world-building, and atmosphere. It tells the best over-arching story of all three games, and has a mixture of good combat and good atmosphere. Stalker Clear Sky has my favorite combat and gameplay of the series, but it seriously lacks purpose and meaning. It DOES have atmosphere, but not in the lonely, horrifying way SoC and CoP focus on.Stalker Call of Pripyat has the best atmosphere, focusing more on side-missions and powerful events, but it doesn't feel like anything massive is going on. You're a guy in the Zone who has a hard life and sees bad things. The atmosphere here is perfect BECAUSE you aren't important, but the sense of scale is toned back. Stalker SoC doesn't do combat or agency as well as Clear Sky, and it doesn't do gripping side-missions and stories like CoP, but it DOES build the world for them to exist in. Without SoC's worldbuilding, Clear Sky and CoP wouldn't have as much oomph as they do. You wouldn't feel as connected to the Zone. You wouldn't be a stalker. Which is why you're here anyways, right? Buy SoC and play it first. Get connected, have some feels, get cheeki breeki. Play Clear Sky and operate with other stalkers. Feel cool. Rage at the bugs. Then buy CoP and play it last. Let it translate all the feelings you've developed into one concise experience. It'll make a lasting impression on you. Then get ready for the memes. If you've gotten through the first, you've essentially branded "im a dank slav" on your chest. Have fun. You're in the cool kids club now.

content:
er 17, 2011
												This game was phoooking pwnage for its time! What makes it great is not what you get whilst you play it, but rather  the eerie industrial feeling you get after you've completed it.It's definitely a 35 hour game. And you'll know whether you like it within 8 hours. It's definitely not a game where you can stop for a few days, play some other game and then resume it. You have to play it in one go.There are several endings. I think 5 wishmaker endings and 2 real endings to the game. The wishmaker endings are based on how you played the game right from the start.A lot of reading, but I reckon it added production value. I couldn't imagine S.T.A.L.K.E.R with characters speaking directly to me. It just wouldn't have been the same.Memorable moments:- Some invisible monster in a dark underground tunnel.- Some area where the whole screen goes yellowish and you see apparitions.- Chernobyl, obviously ... and the abandoned city that surrounds it.- The end talk about C-Consciousness.

content:
er 26, 2015
												Amazing game. 9/10Graphics are all right, and for a game made in 2007, they're pretty good. Gameplay is good, combat is phenomenal and so immersive, AI is good but can't take cover, throw grenades and so on. Story is great, multiple endings. Music is fantastic, sounds are beautiful, but limited. Not much voice acting, except for combat, where it's hilarious cause they speak russian and I don't.Great storyline, and immersiveness. Has proper multiple endings, including 3 endings which you can fail in and obviously this ends the game earlier. Super immersiveness, great environment, ambient sounds and okay stealth system. My only major problem is no fast travel, so if you wanna go back to earlier areas you have to walk there, which takes like an hour if you have reached the Duty base.Another problem is that you can't fix items, so if your weapons starts jamming or your suit is damaged, you can't repair 'em and you have to buy new ones, and that's super expensive.Lovely game. Spent well over 400 hours playing it.Never tried multiplayer.

												This is the most atmospheric shooter I've ever played. I only played this game with the complete mod and not the original. Gameplay:+Immersive times 20!+Great sense of character progression without being an RPG+Long+Above average AI (they actually do something instead of just stand there and shoot) +Multiple endings +Exploration is tense and extremely enjoyable-Glitchy as ♥♥♥♥ Graphics:+Fantastic art design+Environments feel european +Interesting enemy design-Character models and animation is quite datedSound:+Music is great and draws the player in+Ambient sound effects are awesome, form the wind to the fires, to the dudes playing guitar by the fires +/- Guns sound realistic (not everyone likes this as most games go for a bass heavy, fake, movie sound design when it come to guns) I recommend this game at any price point. It's on sale often, so if you still havent tried this... get it!

content:
, 2014
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is a first person shooter survival game. The description is accurate if not complete, because this game is a lot more, I would add sandbox and exploration to the mix at least. I will come back to this a bit later in the review. You start the game in a rather nondescript way, you were left for dead in a field and wake up in the fringes of the "zone" with no memory. By investigating and exploring the "Zone" , a large exclusion perimeter of roughly 30 sq kilometers around Chernobyl which have been sealed off by the Ukrainian army, you hope to regain your memory and discover the place secrets. The "zone" is very dangerous, not only because of all the bandits , trigger happy military, mutants  and mercenaries roaming the place, but also the "natural" phenomenons called anomalies that will shreds you to pieces, burn you alive or electrify you depending of the type if you step on the wrong place. There is offcourse the radiations areas you must avoid in order to survive. The zone contains lot of treasures to find however , mysterious artifacts that can be very valuable and "caches" of gear left over by other lesser fortunate stalker which you have to find. Those treasures and caches give an incentiv for you to explore the «zone» desolate landscape with it's abandonned factories and villages following the 1986 disaster. The people behind the game made a really good work depicting the zone and people who grew up in the 80's and 90s and have seen reports from the Chernobyl disaster in the medias will recognise several landmarks , like the famous  wheel of Pritpjat or the Chernobyl plant itself. The SGS Gameworld team did an excellent work at rendering the place in a very realistic way and at time I marveled of the landscapes of the ruined area in all their sadness. All in all the atmosphere in this game is topnotch and it makes even the most mundane generated quest an experience as you get to explore all those places , abandoned villages and ruined factories with the leftover of old trucks and cars there and here , a sad but beautiful reminder of the madness and destructiveness of human civilization. The inhabitants of the zone are no less fascinating, and not all are enemies bend on killing you. many are stalkers like you or mercenaries hoping to find the mysterious but dangerous riches the zone has to offer. At night you might you might encounter small groups gathering around small fires telling stories , laughing (in russian) or playing the guitare. This gives an human dimension to the people of the place, stalkers like you trying to make it. The story in the game is also very good if not always very clear, especially in those days when we're  tea spooned feed in other games plotwise, S.T.A.L.K.E.R let you do a lot of guesswork on what is really going on, and the answers you get from the plot usually set up more questions. Even the discoveries you make in the game are up to discussion about their meanings. Having finished the game which has no less than two distinct ending, and several versions of those ending depending of your gamestyle and decisions, I personally loved it but it's probably not everyones cup  of tea if you desire a more traditional tale with a “everybody lived happily ever after” end.  It must be said that the game has been partly inspired by the Sovietic art film directed by Stratovsky, Stalker taking on question as existentialism and human potential ,  you will find many elements from the movie in the game although it goes less into philosophy . Just like it's cinematic counterpart S.T.A.L.K.E.R isn't easy to gauge, let's just say it's a great experience gamewise.The gameplay in S.T.A.L.K.E.R isn't very varied, but what it does, it does well. We've gone into the sandbox and exploration part of the game, but S.T.A.L.K.E.R is a competant first person shooter in it's own right, I found the enemies to be challenging and at time rather smart, hiding from me and trying to flank me or throwing grenades at me when possible. During the game you discover many different guns and rifles, both of Russian and Western fabrication. Although I'm not a gun specialist, I found the weapon system to be rather realistic and entertaining, with the weapons themselves true copies of the originals, mostly weapons dating from the 70 to the 90's, something you'd probably find if you were stuck in a postsovietic zone in the near future. The quests , especially the generated ones,  can be rather bland but the great atmosphere of the game saved it from being a shore. While the main story was quite entertaining and really catched my interest through the game. It must be said the game could be rather creepy if not directly scary at time while you explore abandoned depots teaming with dangerous mutants and hidden enemies in the dark. I was a bit annoyed toward the end of the game when I was rather suddently forced to change my gamestyle from “crawling and shooting” which I had done in the majority of the game to “running and shooting” as I had helicopters shooting at me , leaving me no chance to challenge them. Other annoyances would be the bugs, although I played the “complete Mod” which eliminated many of them , I had a few crashes , but nothing gamebreaking. All in all I can only recommend this game (which I would recommend to play with a Mod to eliminate the bugs), a competant shooter with a good if a bit convoluted plot  and a great atmosphere than very few games can measure themselves with. This game is quite old (from 2003) but has a vibrant community who deliver new mods and addons to improve the original product to this day.

content:
er 31, 2013
 Originally posted on January 28, 2009 When I first heard of STALKER, it was the graphics and spooky atmosphere that impressed me. That was over 5 years ago. Since then it has undergone a convoluted and long development process, which left many to believe the game was dead. Well, the finished product is pretty good, despite some bugs and missing features.You play the role of marked one, in a subtle and chilling story about genetics and radiation experiments in the Chernobyl disaster zone. The place is full of mutants and warring bandits, loners, and factions, and is one of the most atmospheric games I've played.Graphics- The technical visuals are quite solid, as the engine was updated since they originally started development. Shadows cast during storms and by lights stand out in particular. The draw distance is decent enough to make you feel like you're actually in the world, and the animations and effects are quite good.Sound- The sound design in this game is top notch, you can hear every clap of thunder or rustle in the grass, but the gunfire is what really stands out. You can hear every distant shot fired at you and the sound of bullets whizzing by inches from your head.Gameplay- This game has some really incredible survival mechanics. You are forced to scavenge for ammo, food, water, and other survival essentials, or buy them at inflated prices from the few merchants in "The Zone". Your inventory allows you to carry a reasonable amount of supplies, but you will get tired quickly if carrying too much. The game does not rely on any traditional RPG stats, but you can improve your chances of survival by finding, stealing, or buying better armor, from simple kelvar-cloth hybrids to full military exoskeletons. You can also obtain a wide breadth of real world guns to fit your playstyle, and they fire a variety of ammunition types, adding another gameplay dynamic. Finally you can find "artifacts" out in the zone's many radiation anomalies which can reduce the damage you take from radtiation, boost your health, and increase your stamina, among other things. They also sell for a pretty penny, if you prefer not to be irradiated by artifacts.The zone itself is an interesting and varied wasteland, with some interesting characters and fedgling game dynamics like random bandit attacks on stalker camps (which you have no obligation to assist) and faction alliances.However, the game world is rather linear and segmented, it is a far cry from a true open game world like in the elder scrolls series. Also, the while the main quest and random encounters and factions battles are compelling enough, the minor quests given to you by traders and others feel really generic, like an after thought to the game. They are entirely random and never run out, unlike other games, in their defense. The factions feel like a remnant from alpha- they hardly ever leave their bases and go on raids (except the military) and they have very limited reactions to your actions beyond friend or enemy.The game has been patched and is no longer the buggy release I was told about a while ago.Value- The game can take anywhere from 25-40 hours to complete, but I would advise you to take your time, and explor to find the really rare weapons and gear, and meet all the interesting people. I probably spent closer to 65 hours playing it, which is not bad for a game i got for $5 on steam. It is a good deal even for the current going price of $20.Overall, I would say try this game if a spooky survival shooter with some really original ideas sounds appealing to you. I am excited to see how clear sky plays in comparison, and what else GSC has up their sleeves.

content:
r 18, 2016
Originally posted by Wish Granter: Idi ko mne.	S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is an action survival horror game set in GSC Game World's vision of 2012 Chernobyl. You are in control of the Marked One, a stalker who was found left for dead in a "death truck" by a fellow stalker. You are taken to Sidorovich and from there on forward you do quests, all in order to solve the mystery of The Zone and figure out who you are.The game has amazing atmosphere whilst still retaining fun gameplay. Despite being well armed and protected, you will never feel safe in S.T.A.L.K.E.R. The game also boasts artifacts: risk/reward items that give you bonus stats in risk of taking radiation (rarer artifacts in the game have bonuses without dealing radiation). There is a varied arsenal in S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl, from Makarovs to the classic AK to shotguns to Gauss Rifles. Despite what some people might say, even on my medium range rig I did not experience crashing at all and unmodded the game ran very smoothly. There and there you can experience hiccups while the game is loading in various elements of the map (especially when you are running it for the first time of the day). The game has quick loading times except the first one which takes a fair bit of time, but it's all smooth sailing from there. However, the games vanilla stealth is very limited and you can't sneak kill that many enemies a la Metro 2033.One thing I'd like to mention is S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl's modding community. It is still very active to this day, with various amazing mods like Autumn Aurora 2, L.U.R.K., STALKERSOUP and Zone Reclamation Project. For a first time playthrough, I'd recommend playing vanilla to get a feel of the game before trying out these mods.Overall, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is an amazing game and it's the only game like it out there, so play it before you forget about it. And then play the other two games and turn into a cheeki breeki in real life. 9/10

												A pretty neat game made by a small Ukrainian studio that only made RTS games prior. It was stuck in development hell from 2000 to 2007, mostly in part because of the fact that an entire new engine had to be made for it that Quake or Unreal couldn't do.This game is noted for its very good ambience and portrayal of environments, being very detailed. While the textures are not exactly great and you can tell the game is dated by playing vanilla, there are mods out there to improve on what's already there.

content:
er 31, 2013
 Originally posted on January 28, 2009 When I first heard of STALKER, it was the graphics and spooky atmosphere that impressed me. That was over 5 years ago. Since then it has undergone a convoluted and long development process, which left many to believe the game was dead. Well, the finished product is pretty good, despite some bugs and missing features.You play the role of marked one, in a subtle and chilling story about genetics and radiation experiments in the Chernobyl disaster zone. The place is full of mutants and warring bandits, loners, and factions, and is one of the most atmospheric games I've played.Graphics- The technical visuals are quite solid, as the engine was updated since they originally started development. Shadows cast during storms and by lights stand out in particular. The draw distance is decent enough to make you feel like you're actually in the world, and the animations and effects are quite good.Sound- The sound design in this game is top notch, you can hear every clap of thunder or rustle in the grass, but the gunfire is what really stands out. You can hear every distant shot fired at you and the sound of bullets whizzing by inches from your head.Gameplay- This game has some really incredible survival mechanics. You are forced to scavenge for ammo, food, water, and other survival essentials, or buy them at inflated prices from the few merchants in "The Zone". Your inventory allows you to carry a reasonable amount of supplies, but you will get tired quickly if carrying too much. The game does not rely on any traditional RPG stats, but you can improve your chances of survival by finding, stealing, or buying better armor, from simple kelvar-cloth hybrids to full military exoskeletons. You can also obtain a wide breadth of real world guns to fit your playstyle, and they fire a variety of ammunition types, adding another gameplay dynamic. Finally you can find "artifacts" out in the zone's many radiation anomalies which can reduce the damage you take from radtiation, boost your health, and increase your stamina, among other things. They also sell for a pretty penny, if you prefer not to be irradiated by artifacts.The zone itself is an interesting and varied wasteland, with some interesting characters and fedgling game dynamics like random bandit attacks on stalker camps (which you have no obligation to assist) and faction alliances.However, the game world is rather linear and segmented, it is a far cry from a true open game world like in the elder scrolls series. Also, the while the main quest and random encounters and factions battles are compelling enough, the minor quests given to you by traders and others feel really generic, like an after thought to the game. They are entirely random and never run out, unlike other games, in their defense. The factions feel like a remnant from alpha- they hardly ever leave their bases and go on raids (except the military) and they have very limited reactions to your actions beyond friend or enemy.The game has been patched and is no longer the buggy release I was told about a while ago.Value- The game can take anywhere from 25-40 hours to complete, but I would advise you to take your time, and explor to find the really rare weapons and gear, and meet all the interesting people. I probably spent closer to 65 hours playing it, which is not bad for a game i got for $5 on steam. It is a good deal even for the current going price of $20.Overall, I would say try this game if a spooky survival shooter with some really original ideas sounds appealing to you. I am excited to see how clear sky plays in comparison, and what else GSC has up their sleeves.

content:
er 23, 2016
												One of my favorites. Not totally unforgiving, but challenging. Tense as hell in dark corridors and the sounds literally make me jump out of my chair. Fighting against a squad of 8, took out 3, and im listening/looking for them. Most of them sounded or look like they've run off to re-organize, before I move on, I suddenly hear an AKM-74/2U  directly to my right and "Game Over". Forgot to check my right, and a soldier ambushed me.Scariest. Thing. Ever.
